title: Discussion Panel: Maximising Innovation Potential Through Diversity in Research Organisations

author: Gülsün Sağlamer, Center for Rebuilding Sustainable Communities after Disasters, University of Massachusetts Boston
chairman: Judith Abrahami, ORT Braude College of Engineering

segmentation: Distinguished colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, it's a great pleasure, an honor for me to be here and to have a chance to address you.
I would like to thank the organizers of this meeting for inviting me here, so then I will have a chance to talk a little bit about my country.
Which is not very well known by many European colleagues.

And in this presentation I will just give brief introduction about gender issue an then will continue in the analysis of the Mediterranean basin that we did a small quantitative pilot study that I would like to share some of the things that we.
He articulated, after the analysts of this small work, and then the other give you some information about Turkish case, and then my University and some observations, and at the end a question.
I don't think that I will have a time to inform you about some results from the meta analysis of gender and Science project which has some interesting.
Results related to this project.
Gendera project, but it they will be in the slide.
So if anybody wants to see them then they can look at them there.
So innovation is one of the most important agenda item on European Commission and on the university's agenda as well and.
21st century will be a time of rapid innovation and technological change that will be spurred on the grand challenges that we face, including climate change and the demand.
So an aging society.
So this is.
Challenges that we are facing in the coming years are the most important problems that we are facing in the human history I believe.
So on the other hand, if you look at the European Commission's policy papers that our colleagues explained here very well.
European Commission in recent years give great importance to innovation and the paper that they communicate that published.
They published in 2010.
Was about it was titled Innovation Union.
An afterwards than you a framework program is called Horizon 2020, in which industry and University partnership is giving great importance.
So under these circumstances.
I like to ask a question.
Will there be a substantial role to play for women in the coming years?
Becausw as I asked my colleague before when we look at the representation of women in industry, we see that it is less than the government and University sector.
So under these circumstances it may be difficult to have a substantial role to play for women in the coming year.
So we have to.
Prepare ourselves in order to have the good results in.
Coming.
We all know that gender inequality issue is a problem which is as old as human history and we have reasons not to be there over optimistic in our expectations.
When we remember that women were accepted to colleges and universities only 150 years ago, we should be patient and persistent about reaching the substantive improvements that we seek.
One can hope that in an era or accelerated.
Accelerating change Jane gender mainstreaming will eventually come to be actualized.
We know that women now constitute about 50% or first degree students in many countries all over the world, including Europe.
In the northern part of Europe it is even more than 50%.
There are considerable variations in the proportion of women students between disciplines.
This is horizontal segregation.
The percentage of full professors who are women is very low worldwide.
For the most part, below 15%, this is vertical segregation.
You all know this, but when it is called scissors scissors diagram.
But when it comes to science, engineering and technology, there is no Caesar.
In fact it doesn't.
The If the lines doesn't crossing each other.
There is a very interesting index used by a.
She figures by the European Commission.
It shows where the glass ceiling is very thick and when we look at this histogram, if the glass ceiling index is 1, it means there is equilibrium there.
If it is less than one, it means males females are dominating.
Environment if it is bigger than one, it means males are dominating the environment.
So when we look at here, we see that Turkey has the minimum glassy link index.
I am sure that most of our colleagues do not expect this result.
Becausw Turkey is a Islamic country near to Middle East and nobody expects Turkey to have such a.
A good performance in terms of glass ceiling index, but that's the fact that I like to share with you.
We have carried out a pilot study on the female researchers in the European Union Member States an associate countries.
And Portugal, Spain, France, Italy, Malta, Croatia, Slovenia, Greece, Turkey and Cyprus.
We have aimed to map the situation or female researchers with special regards to gender differences in research careers and critical areas where women are underrepresented.

We have observed the important variations among the Mediterranean countries in this under representation and the peculiarities observed in science engineer can technology you may ask, why did you choose Mediterranean country countries to carry out this analysis?
Because we see that there are big cultural differences between South and North West and East.
So we wanted to have rather consistent countries to carry out this analysis.
Here.
If you look at the proportion of female researchers.
Anne, excluding France and Malta.
Older Mediterranean countries have better performance than EU 27.
This is a good sign because the number of female researchers are really very high and the.
Here Croatia and Portugal are the leading countries in in this respect and Spain, Turkey and Greece are doing really slow and you're doing really very good performance.
And in order to have a impact on innovation you have to have many female researchers.
So these are the.
This is the promising picture I believe.
Of course, our target should be to reach 50%, but at the moment that's the situation.
What's the proportion of female female researchers by sector?
If you look at them higher education, government sector and business enterprise, we seed.
We see that in most of the countries, government sector is the leading sector.
An higher education is comes second and the business enterprise is the third one.

If you look at the patterns, we can see that there are similarities between Turkey and France in terms of distribution of female researchers among sectors becausw in both countries, universities have the largest number of female researchers than the government sector.
The third party is the business, but the rest of the countries have a government sector.
Is the leading sector.
If you look at the proportion of female researchers in the higher education sector by field of science, we can see that this is very important in terms of horizontal segregation.
Spain has the.
Baby has the most.
He developed distribution among among different fields of science.
Almost all the researchers are distributed to all the fields at the same rate.
But if we look at Cyprus and Malta, they're small countries an it is very difficult to get good statistical.
You know figures from those countries, but the rest of the countries are having similar proofs, similar structure and Portugal, Croatia, Turkey, Italy.
They're all slowing at.
They're all in good shape, but the best one is Spain.
Let's have a look to the proportion of the great a position in this respect.
Turkey is the leading country it was in 2002.
It was 25% of the female.
25% of the full professors were female and it went up to 28% in the last five years, 28% in the last five years.
So Turkey is the leading country.
You may ask me why this is the result, but I will answer them during the discussions.
But this is a very, very striking figure.
I believe for Turkey.
A proportional academic staff by great and total by two by the year 2007.
Great a great be, great C&D and total.
It is very important to see that engineering.
Sorry it is very interesting to see that the.
Kriti is increasing, and it means that it will have reflection in the coming years because some of the countries has already reached 50% at that level.
So it means that in the coming 10 years, we may expect to have more women at upper positions.
But we have to also look at the histograms carefully.
Becausw, when you look at Turkish case, it is very.
The pipeline is not really a leaking very much, but when you look at for example.
He Spain they have 48% of their degrade proportion, but when it comes to professors it goes down to 18%.
So the pipeline is leaking.
Really this is a very important issue.
How this is Turkish case?
Proportional women academics from 2000 three 2010.
When you look at the professors, it went up to 25% to 28% for the associate professors.
It went up to 32% to 34%.
It's not really big improvement, but for the assistant professors there is a big improvement there.
From 30% it went up to 46%, so we're hoping that as we have the minimum glass ceiling index, we're hoping that in the coming years the upper.
Positions will be much more better than before.
I I like to bring this a example into your attention.
I try to compare Swedish case with Turkish case.
When you look at the pH D degree holders in Sweden, 50% of them female an in Turkey it's 42% first academic employment in Sweden 41%.
Associate professors 38 and professors 20%.
But in Turkey it starts with 242%.
It goes down to 28 now 27% by the year 2008.
We have a good.
Profile, but when it comes to top decision-making positions, it's not like that in Sweden, 45% of directors are female.
It went down to 40% this year, but still is very high percentage.
But in Turkey it's only eight 9%.
It fluctuates but it never goes up to 10% so.
You can see that we have a good profile in terms of academic distribution, but when it comes to decision-making positions, it's not the same.
There is another important success for Turkish universities.
An important fact has been outlined on the Mail over representation.
Factoring King computer science.
According to the research has been conducted at the University of California.
Turkey has the minimum male over representation factor in computer science among 21 countries.
Again, Turkey is a leading country in computer science in terms of female.
Represente
Now this is my University, I was the I'm the first female vice Rector.
An first female rector of my University.
After 220 years it is the oldest Technical University in my country.
All the University.
It's one of the oldest Technical University in Europe is the fifth one in Europe.
Istanbul Technical University Ann.
I was the first female.
Why sector and the first rector of my University served between 1996 two 1004?
So I like to draw your attention to the period that I was.
The director of my University, you see that between 95 and 2005 we did this analysis under the unique cafe project, so I would like to thank Dora Grow and Maria Palasik.
They're here, so it created a lot of impact on our University Unicover project.
So in this in this in these figures you can see that there's a big jump.
Between the figures, professors increased from 16% to 929%.
Associate professors 31% to 36% assistant professors.
We made a big jump here 28% to 46%, so the research assistance from 20% to 37%.
So during this.
I haven't done anything.
Two, I didn't put any quarter, but I believe that I was setting a role model.
This is the first one, the Secondly I had a chance to construct nurseries, primary schools, high schools, campus housing.
Four mainly for a female academics.
This created a lot of impact.
On the other hand, I was so sensitive when we were forming promotion committees and research project committees, including women in those committees.
So all of those things worked in a very positive way and created this result.
After I left, I can see that there is no big.
Increase in professorship and then.
Maybe associate professors increased?
But there's a big decline in assistant professors.
And the research assistants kept increasing, so it's a good profile that my University has been developing good gender.
Environment where we have been able to increase the total number of 28% up to 39% in 15 years.
If you look at the master degree students 40.6% or master degree students are female and PhD students.
41.6% of the PhD students are female.
So this is again from unique coffee project.
This is in the middle of the I don't know if it has pointer in the middle of the blue and purple color triangle signs showed it you case we have the minimum gap between men and women academics here.
I would like to draw your attention to the success rates of female students.
Female students ratio is 30% in our University students average grades in 2008, 2009 for the autumn term females 2002.60 and spring term 2.54.
But when it comes to male students.
For the autumn term two point 12.
Spring term 2.06.
So the girls are having zero point 50.
Great, more in average then male students.
An when it comes to top three in graduations in 2008.
2009 for the first winning price, 39% of female for the second, 52% of female, for the third 40% or female in total 44% female students got the prices although they only form.
30% of the total students.
Proportion of female students in higher education in Turkey.
44% of total I'd education students are female.
46% of total graduating students are female.
Again.
We can see the same thing 2% more than their existence.
49% of total graduate program students are female.
We have a technology development zone where we have technology, techno parks and we have we have the most successful techno parks in our University.

You can see the figures that among 22 we have to enter two techno parks in Turkey but 47 of percent of the patterns and the 37% of the trademarks and 45% of budget and things like that they belong to this.
A techno.
Park where we have a.
Put under 1094 women researchers among.
1990 this is small number.
That's what I try to explain to you.
And again we have 5 RND company CEOs female among.
78 So this is a very small number, so there are businesses that we have to deal with this problem.
So some observations, the proportion of female students at every level of higher education keep increasing in Turkey.
In Europe everywhere female students interest on science engineer engineer can.
Technology is also increasing but slower than the increase in higher education in general.
Success rates of female students are higher than males in many countries, but.
Female students tend to concentrate on certain field of study areas.
There they do not.
They are not interested in all the fields at the same level.
Promotional female academics is a leaky pipeline.
Female researchers have less ambition to be in leading position.
An credit that they achieve usually go to male boss that our colleague mentioned before.
An equality equal opportunities policies having marginal effect in terms of access.
An employment, academic merit and Leko strong commitment for equity policies in the institution make the life difficult for female researchers.
So how to maximize innovation potential?
Is it possible maximising innovation potential through diversity in research organizations?
I think yes it is possible if you are able to decide to use human capital efficiently and effectively if you are committed to do it.
Yes, it is possible.

And to prepare the condition for this transformation is very important because if we do not provide nurseries infrastructure to make the women researchers happy in their environment, how can we expect them to compete with their male counterparts?
It is really difficult.
We have to create gender friendly environment.
We have to remove barriers for every kind of segregation.
We have to empower and strengthen the capacity of women to be able to compete in equal conditions with self confidence.
So that's all.
Thank you very much.
